back:
An ordered collection of numbers that has an accompanying set of
  mathematical operations.

The number of axes used to index the contents of a
  mathematical object, such as a vector, matrix,  or tensor.
A single numerical value.
One of the numerical values that make up the vector.
One of the numerical values that make up the vector.
The number of components a vector contains.

A (two-dimensional) plot that illustrates one or more
  vectors as arrows that are typically specified by a location, which determines
  the coordinates of the tail of the vector, and some specification of the
  direction and magnitude of the vector. If no location is provided, then the
  origin $(0,0)$ is used.

The \textit{tail} of a vector is the starting point of a vector (the initial
point from which the displacement is measured).

The \textit{head} of a vector is the ending point of a vector (the point
  at which the vector terminates after the specified displacement from the tail).

A (two-dimensional) scatter plot takes a sequence of
  two-dimensional data points $(x_0, y_0)$, $(x_1, y_1)$, $\ldots$, $(x_{n-1},
  y_{n-1})$ and plots symbols (called \textit{markers}) that represent the
  locations of the points in a rectangular region of a plane.

Data that is collected over time, usually at regular
  intervals. Each data point is associated with a timestamp indicating when the
  data was collected.

Most commonly used with categorical data for which each category has an associated
  quantity or measurement, a bar is drawn for each category, where the height or
  width of the bar is proportional to the associated quantity or measurement.
A vector of all zeros.
A vector of all ones.
A vector with all of its components equal to zero, except one element that is equal to one.

The sum of $n$ vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) and
  \(\mathbf{b}\) is a vector \(\mathbf{a+b}\) such that any component $i$ of the
  vector sum is the sum of the \(i\)th components of \(\mathbf{a}\) and
  \(\mathbf{b}\); i.e.
  \begin{equation*}\mathbf{(a+b)}_i = a_i + b_i,~~i=0, 1,\ldots, n-1.\end{equation*}

The sum of $n$ vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) and

%   \(\mathbf{b}\); i.e. \(\mathbf{(a+b)}_i = a_i + b_i,~~i=0, 1,\ldots, n-1\).

Given a vector \(\mathbf{u}\) and a
  scalar \(\alpha\), define \(\alpha \mathbf{u}\) such that each component
  \(i\) of \(\alpha \mathbf{u}\) is given by \((\alpha \mathbf{u})_i = \alpha
  u_i\). Thus,
  \begin{equation*

In NumPy, broadcasting occurs in operations
  involving two arrays of different shapes. The smaller array is
  \textit{broadcast} across the larger array by repeating values in the smaller
  array in such a way that the shapes of the two arrays will match.

front:
component-wise multiplication (vectors) 
 or 
 Hadamard product (vectors) 
 or 
 Schur product (vectors)
back:
Given \(n\)-vectors \(\mathbf{u}\) and \(\mathbf{v}\), the \textit{Hadamard product} or \textit{Schur product} is denoted \(\mathbf{u} \odot \mathbf{v}\) and is the \(n\)-vector given by component-wise multiplication of \(\mathbf{u}\) and \(\mathbf{v}\),
  \begin{equation*

Given \(n\)-vectors \(\mathbf{u}\) and \(\mathbf{v}\), the \textit{dot product} or \textit{inner product} is denoted \(\mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{v}\) or \(\mathbf{u}^\tran \mathbf{v}\) and is the \textbf{scalar value} given by multiplying corresponding components and summing them up:
  \begin{equation*

A vector \(\mathbf{v}\) is a \textit{unit vector} if \(\| \mathbf{v} \| =1.\)

Given \(n\)-vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\), the \textit{scalar projection} of \(\mathbf{b}\) onto \(\mathbf{a}\) has magnitude equal to the length of the vector in the direction of \(\mathbf{a}\) that minimizes the error to \(\mathbf{b}\).
